sense.name: travel on a body of water (propelled by wind)
sense.commentary:
NP1[+agent] SAIL NP2[+concrete]
NOTE: Includes metaphorical uses. The NP2 does not need to be specified, but it does need to be implied as in the last example.
sense.examples: Charles Darwin sailed on the Beagle. I love sailing the open sea. Who 'really' sailed the Ocean Blue in 1492? Can a kitten sail a ship? There was a lady who sailed my soul. We sailed (the ocean) through the night.

sense.name: move with sweeping, effortless gliding motions
sense.examples: Jeanette sailed into the ballroom with a grin. The paper airplane sailed through the air. The glider sailed down to a perfect landing.

sense.name: SAIL THROUGH: succeed at easily or finish quickly
sense.commentary:
Is: SAIL THROUGH
NOTE: is only metaporical uses NOT involving water or a vehicle.
sense.examples: I'm sailing through my Linguistics class. Does he expect to sail through his entire college carreer? The market researcher sailed through the 100 question survey.
